channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: NLP is all right by me! Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: A global leader in machine intelligence matching job seekers with their perfect career: our client’s goal is human level parsing. They’re on the hunt for an NLP Engineer whose passion for NLP is matched only by their interest in Machine Intelligence and their ability to drive quality improvements, measurement standards, and error analysis processes for the NLP framework.

item.title: Thought-Leader Wanted. Chief Software Architect role in Malaysia
item.description: As Chief Software Architect for an international company providing online trading services, you’ll work closely with the Chief Technology Officer. With a strong understanding of the full stack of software development and cloud technologies, you’ll mentor engineering teams and provide guidance in solving technical issues.

item.title: Is your Python as good as your Perl? Perl/Python role in London
item.description: Our client is at the pinnacle of the premium native advertising game for corporate, tech, financial services, and lifestyle technology. This role is for a Senior Developer who is equally comfortable with Perl AND Python.

item.title: Music-loving DevOps (with Perl), get in here! London based role
item.description: We’ve got an intriguing role for a Lead DevOps Engineer who cares about great music. Our client knows all about how you listen to music: as an independent global music business, they work with artists, labels, and distributors to release and sell music on their digital platform. Perl experience would be helpful, and knowledge of Linux, configuration management tooling like Ansible or Puppet, and e

item.title: Good (Perl) Humans Wanted. Remote Perl role in USA
item.description: Working with first responders, educators, manufacturers, and engineers, our client is the leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions. They’re looking for a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBIx::Class. Open to candidates within similar US time zones.

item.title: Charlotte PM Richard Hipp Talks About All Things SQLite
item.description: Wednesday, May 25, 2022; 06:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PWC 164 › Happy Numbers
item.description: Ryan shared the secret $_ * $_ is better than $_ ** 2, something I never looked at closely. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC 164 › Palindromic Primes
item.description: Cool observation about Palindrone Primes. So organised blog, not to be missed. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Happy Palindromes
item.description: Rust is pick of the language for blog this week. I must admit, it is very impressive. Thanks for your contributions as always.

item.title: Palindromic primes and moody numbers
item.description: Breaking task into simple and easy steps makes it lots of fun. Amazing quality to have, thanks for sharing your knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 164
item.description: Luis consistent one-liner in Perl is the highlight every week. Thank you for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 164: quick and easy
item.description: Luca came up with yet another Raku magical solutions. Like always we got bonus with PostgreSQL solution too. Thank you for everything.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 164: Prime Palindromes and Happy Numbers
item.description: Raku at its best but Perl is also not far behind. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 164
item.description: James golf solution is worth checking out. The bonus optimized and cache solutions not to missed. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 164
item.description: Cool one-liner in Raku for Palindrome Prime is great example showing the power of Raku. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC164 - Happy Numbers
item.description: Flavio showing off Raku power using Unicode operator. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC164 - Prime Palindrome
item.description: Cool one-liner in Perl using home grown subroutines makes it attractive. Well done. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Shiny Happy Numbers
item.description: Nice attempt to get one-liner in Perl. Very impressive, keep it up great work.

item.title: Happy Happy Joy Joy
item.description: Background of the task Happy Numbers is really cool, something I wish I knew before. I can't thank you enough for your contributions.

item.title: Primarily Happy
item.description: Finding the number of steps to get to the Happy Numbers is nice hack. Thanks for your contributions as always.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Alexander Pankoff
item.description: Please checkout the interview with the latest champion of the month April 2022.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 164
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Prime Palindrome" and "Happy Numbers" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 165
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG)" and "Line of Best Fit". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Getopt::Long long options can be case-sensitive
item.description: It is something that I didn't know before. How can I miss it? Thank you for keeping the daily blog alive.

item.title: Common Problems in Object-Oriented Code
item.description: Although it is generic discussion not just about Perl. Highly recommended.

item.title: Towards Perl 5.36 - try/catch/finally
item.description: I always wish for finally block and it seems we are getting it soon. Thank you for sharing the good news.

item.title: My Favorite Modules: Errno
item.description: Nice introduction to Errno with apt example to get the point across.

item.title: #564 - Issues with OOP?
item.description:
Hi there,

I am a big fan OOP and can't wait to see Modern Object in Perl, Corinna, to be part of core Perl. Last update I had was in early January by Curtis. You can checkout the details here.

If you are new to Corinna then I would recommend you checkout this post by Curtis. Those who don't know, Curtis is leading the team working on Corinna.

Talking about OOP, I came across another post by none other than Curtis himself sharing the common issues with OO code. This should be taught to anyone starting OO in any language and not just Perl, in my humble opinion. Having read it few times already from start to end in one go, I keep going back to it to keep myself reminded about it all the time. You would definitely want to bookmark it for future reference.

Few weeks ago, I shared post Why is Object-Oriented Programming Bad? by Curtis. My favourite line in the post, "I think there’s a good case to be made that OOP is not nearly as useful as it’s claimed.". Mind you, this is coming from Curtis.

Enough of OO, lets talk about Exceptions in Perl, I would like to share the blog post by Curtis (once again), where he points out the common issue in Perl. It reminded me about my recent post sharing the new try/catch block in Perl v5.34.

Last but not the least, please find this gem by Curtis talking about testing database operations with a fresh instance of SQLite everytime. I wonder, if this can be shared as CPAN module. Just thinking out loud, I know.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
